ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My abilities in real analysis improved a lot.

There is a lot of overlap from Math 305, but there's still some interesting results that can be developed so the class is still fairly worth it (general measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym, Hilbert/Banach spaces, ergodic theory).

The course covers the core topics in real analysis from the basic construction of measure theory and Lebesgue measure, through integration, Lp spaces, and finishing with the Hahn-Banach theorem and Hilbert spaces.
Measure theory and the theory of Lp spaces in general.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think it's a very good and thorough introduction to graduate level analysis. There is a good deal of overlap with material from 305, so if anything more new topics would be appreciated!

The workload was quite reasonable, though made easier because the material should be very familiar. Professor Gekhtman is very nice and helpful to talk to, particularly during office hours. I do wish we had gotten grades back more frequently, and some times, just at all. The course should use a better textbook, like Folland.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course if you want a strong background in analysis. The course isn't great, but at the end of the problem sets you will have a very strong background in analysis.

I'd definitely recommend it if you want to get a better grip on measure theory coming out of 305; it probably is quite easy to self-study, though. It's got some interesting material. The book is pretty mediocre though; read Folland alongside it to actually learn.

I would definitely recommend to another student wishing to progress in the analysis track of mathematics course from 305. It builds on that material and progresses into the prerequisites of MATH 320 Intro to Functional Analysis.
I would recommend this course to those looking for a solid grounding in measure theory.
